January 13, 2002: Fiction
SKIPPING CHRISTMAS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A husband and
wife discover that their decision to forgo Christmas comes with consequences.
VIOLETS ARE BLUE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) Detective Alex
Cross investigates a series of bizarre murders that appear to be the work of a
vampire.
THE CORRECTIONS, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A
multigenerational saga in which a mother tries to bring her dysfunctional family
together for a final Christmas at home.
LAST MAN STANDING, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.95.) The head of the
F.B.I.'s elite hostage rescue team is the only survivor of a high-tech ambush.
HE SEES YOU WHEN YOU'RE SLEEPING, by Mary Higgins Clark and Carol
Higgins Clark. (Scribner/ Simon & Schuster, $20.) To earn his way into heaven, a
man must save a young girl's family from mobsters.
DESECRATION, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) The
ninth volume of the "Left Behind" series, in which the forces of good battle the
forces of evil after the rapture of the saved.
JACKDAWS, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $26.95.) Shortly before D-Day, a British
operative in France finds herself leading an all-woman team of amateur saboteurs.
JOURNEY THROUGH HEARTSONGS, written and illustrated by Mattie J. T.
Stepanek. (VSP Books, $14.95.) A collection of poems by an 11-year-old boy who
suffers from muscular dystrophy.
ONE DOOR AWAY FROM HEAVEN, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $26.95.) A
woman tries to protect a 9-year-old girl from her stepfather, who is convinced that
her destiny will involve U.F.O.'s and aliens.
THE BEST-LOVED POEMS OF JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS, selected by
Caroline Kennedy. (Hyperion, $21.95.) The former first lady's favorite poems.
BLACK HOUSE, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Random House, $28.95.)
After a retired homicide detective living in Wisconsin tries to help the police solve
brutal murders, he winds up in a parallel universe.
THE KISS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) The wife of a Parisian banker
conducts a long-distance platonic relationship with a Washington power broker.
A BEND IN THE ROAD, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $23.95.) A widower and his
son's second-grade teacher discover that they are linked by a secret.

WHEN CHARACTER WAS KING, by Peggy Noonan. (Viking, $24.95.) Reflections
